So, sueña en grande conmigo and be a part of history in the making!

Please follow us and QRT to share YOUR #HispanicHeritageMonth #SueñoGrande (big dream)."
We can heal the trauma of the outsized impact on Latinx people. We do that by organizing and lobbying for policies that promote #equity, #resilience, and #remembrance.👇🏾

This #HispanicHeritageMonth, I want to not only celebrate our achievements -- past, present, and future -- but acknowledge our struggle and the sacrifices forced upon us by the system that treats us as if we’re expendable when in fact we’re irreplaceable.👇🏾

That’s why @MarkedByCovid is taking a sledgehammer to the cement and advocating for policies that will help all families -- especially BIPOC families -- thrive. This includes #UniversalPreSchool, #StudentLoan forgiveness, #PaidLeave, increased #ChildTaxCredits, and more.👇🏾

These occupations inherently carry more risk of #COVID19 exposure, but families living paycheck-to-paycheck can’t often afford to decline work.

The result? According to the @CDCgov, Latinx people are 2.3x more likely to die from #Covid as their white counterparts.👇🏾

...just like those in health care, restaurant and foodservice, grocery sales, agriculture, building cleaning services, and more.

These positions are disproportionately staffed by Latinx people, pay poverty wages, and don’t come with benefits like health care or paid time off.👇🏾

He was an agricultural worker for more than 65 years in Colorado, Arizona, and California, picking fruits and vegetables in sweltering heat well into his 80s.

Mi abuelo and my father were both “essential..."

When I think of people of color and particularly of folks who are #Latinx, I think of essential workers like my grandfather, Venancio. After losing his father in a ranching accident when he was 15, he traveled to find paying work to support his family living in Durango, Mexico.👇🏾

That cement was poured and reinforced by politicians over generations, creating a system where disparities are the norm and their existence helps reinforce racist tropes that somehow people of color are lazy or less deserving.

Nothing could be further than the truth.👇🏾
The pandemic laid bare what many of us have experienced our whole lives: that a cemented boot can only move so far, no matter your fuerza, hustle, nor smarts.👇🏾

It pushes back against any revisionist history that may emerge in the coming years; it’s easy to imagine accounts that conveniently emphasize health care heroes while waving away how flawed our health care system is...

It validates the experiences of health care workers on the ground, and those of people who are unable to get adequate health care. Acknowledging that our health system did collapse under the weight of the COVID-19 ultimately sets the stage for comprehensive health reform...

"Brink and hedge words like it—cusp, verge, threshold—offer us a state of suspended animation between normalcy and a true crisis. Focusing on language so intently may seem pedantic. But there is power in simply stating the truth...

Today, hospitals are full in much of the country... These are not features of a health system that is approaching failure. These are features of a health care system that has broken down spectacularly, forcing doctors and patients to climb through the rubble looking for help."

Last winter, many hospitals across the country instituted crisis standards of care, forced to ration health services based on criteria that few people envisioned would be used outside of a mass casualty event, like a terrorist attack...

"My time as a doctor has been defined by working in a system that has already collapsed. The American health system I work in has featured limited personal protective equipment, oxygen shortages, and the construction of field hospitals in convention centers and parking garages...

...and everything will be fine. But it is not sustainable, and it is not fine. The health care system is not approaching some kind of cliff, while still functioning—what is happening right now is killing people like Daniel Wilkinson. People who do not have to die are dying."

"To say that we’re on the brink of disaster offers hope that the people in charge can take steps to keep us from plunging toward an abyss. Masking also helps to prevent the virus from circulating, reducing the chances that it will mutate, possibly into a form more virulent that may evade vaccines altogether.

Wearing a mask also helps protect children who can’t be vaccinated yet, and others who are susceptible, like the elderly and those with compromised immune systems, who may not be able to mount a vigorous immune response following vaccination.

Masks “are actually amazing, because they work immediately — they start reducing transmission today,” said @JuliaRaifman, an assistant professor at @BUSPH. “Every case they prevent prevents several other cases, so their effectiveness grows over time.”

In addition to Americans in #Covid19 hot spots, @CDCDirector also recommended universal indoor masking for teachers, staff, students and visitors to schools, regardless of where they are and regardless of individual vaccination status.

An internal presentation circulated within @CDCgov last month offered clear advice for countering the contagious Delta variant: “Given higher transmissibility and current vaccine coverage, ✨universal masking✨ is essential.” https://t.co/ZYS8FHDDHp
